I would like a copy of said report and/or anything else related to this case and the principals. The alleged crime occurred in 1982, and Detective Richard Armstead pursued an Internal Affairs investigation at that time. Furthermore, a Federal Grand Jury was held in 1987 regarding the case. All relevant documents are requested. Thank you.

Peter Dowd In July of 1982, a rape allegedly occurred at the "Silver Shield" club located at 100 Kemble Street, Roxbury. As this was a police officers "after hours" club, and internal affairs investigation was begun in 1982, and in January of 1986 BOD commissioner Mickey Roache announced that a BPD investigation and report had exonerated officers William Dunn and William Kennefick. A federal grand jury was held by Robert Mueller and in March of 1987 it was announced that no indictments were made.

Sara Wilson Lawyers for Civil Rights This letter constitutes a request under the Public Records Law, G.L. c. 66, § 10, for public records in the custody of the Boston Police Department (“BPD”). As used in this request, “record” and “records” are defined as in the Public Records Law; “Non-civil service” is defined as civilian employees; “Zones” or “Districts” are defined as the districts of BPD; “Rank” is defined as the title or position within BPD. Unless otherwise stated, the time period for which records are requested is January 1, 2018, to present day. I hereby request copies of the following documents: 1. All records referring to, indicating or reflecting the overall demographics by gender and race of all civil service employees of the BPD, disaggregated by zones and/or districts and by rank and/or grade. 2. All records referring to, indicating or reflecting the overall demographics by gender and race of all non-civil service employees of the BPD, disaggregated by department, division or unit and by job title. 3. All records drafted, used, or referenced to create employee training for diversity, cultural competency, and/or implicit bias, including, but not limited to, information regarding the various facilitators and/or companies that facilitate the trainings. 4. All records pertaining to BPD’s diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and/or goals, including, but not limited to, BPD trainings, recruitment, hiring, promoting and/or retention of BPD employees. 5. All records pertaining to language access, including, but not limited to, 1) the department’s Language Access Plan (LAP); 2) all vendors used for translation and interpretation services and 3) all policies and procedures pertaining to requests for and the provision of translation and interpretation into languages other than English. 6. All records indicating or reflecting a communication and/or request by BPD to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts’ Human Resources Division (HRD) to consider language skills in the hiring process for BPD employees. 7. All records indicating or reflecting a communication and/or response by HRD to BPD regarding a request to consider language skills in the hiring process for BPD employees. 8. The most recent BPD organizational chart. As this request involves a matter of public concern, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.06(5). The purpose of this request is to gain information about the diversity of a public agency and its efforts to ensure diversity, equity, and inclusion across personnel and policy. The information will not be used for any commercial purpose. If the waiver is denied and you expect the fee to exceed $10.00, please provide a detailed fee estimate. The Public Records Law requires that you comply with this request within 10 days following receipt. If your response to any portion of the request is that any record or portion of it is not public, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such denial, including which specific exemption you believe applies. I can be reached at the contact information below with any questions or concerns regarding this request. CiovO\

Matthew Cahill Boston Finance Commission Please consider the following a formal request for information from the City of Boston Finance Commission. 1. On December 16, 2022, the Finance Commission had a discussion with Director of Active Transportation, Stefanie Seskin. Ms. Seskin stated that there are approximately eighteen current bike lane projects where notifications to local residents were made or being made, and public meetings were held to get resident feedback. She also stated that she had email notification lists to alert people to projects and meetings. - The Finance Commission is requesting a list of project; - the email notification lists for each project; -any hard or electronic correspondences supporting or against the projects; -and the hard copy or electronic sign-in sheets for each public meeting that was held regarding each bike lane project. We are requesting documents from January 1, 2017 to January 1, 2022. 2. The Finance Commission has had a number of email correspondences with Chief of Streets, Jascha Franklin-Hodge. In one of those communications Mr. Franklin-Hodge indicated that it is a regular course of business to conduct informal and formal observations of both temporary and permanent bike lanes throughout the City of Boston. Our presumption, in part, is that these observations are done to evaluate the bike lane utilization, the effectiveness of the bike lane installations, and the impact the bike lane installation is having on the community. The Finance Commission is requesting all documents, work-product, reports, notes, interviews, meeting minutes, emails, correspondences, whether hard copy or electronic communications, relative to all formal and informal observations and evaluations of bike lane installations. We are requesting documents from January 1, 2017 to January 1, 2022. Please note that the Finance Commission made an informal request for these documents to Mr. Franklin-Hodge, which was rejected by him. Kindly provide the requested documents by 5:00 PM, Wednesday, January 26, 2022.

Laura Dorson Massachusetts Institute of Technology We kindly request the following data for academic research purposes. 1) All 911 calls-for- service initiated within the jurisdiction of Boston from January 1, 2015 through December 31, 2021. We ask for the following information to be included for each call: Date & time of call Location of reported incident (e.g., geocoordinates and/or address) Police district or precinct Type of reported incident (e.g., robbery, shooting, etc) Initiator (e.g., civilian, police, shotspotter) Categories of service provider dispatched to call (e.g., police, fire, medical) Date & time service provider is dispatched to incident location Date & time service provider arrives at incident location Disposition (officer reported outcome of the call) Unique identifiers for the call that can be used to tie the call to other datasets maintained by relevant government agencies Any other readily accessible information recorded about the call If certain information is unavailable, we ask for partial fulfillment of the data request. We also ask for the data to be provided in a machine readable format such as a csv file. An example of the type and format of data we are interested in has been posted for Baltimore city here:https://data.baltimorecity.gov/datasets/911-calls-for-service-2020/explore. 2) All stops of persons by the police within the jurisdiction of Boston between January 1, 2015 through December 31, 2021. We ask for the following information to be included for each stop: Date & time of stop Location (e.g., geocoordinates and/or address) Police district or precinct Initiator of the stop (e.g., initiated by officer or call-for-service) Race of the person stopped Disposition (officer reported outcome of the stop) Use-of-force (level of force used in stop, if any) Unique identifiers for the stop that can be used to tie the stop to other datasets maintained by relevant government agencies Any other readily accessible information recorded about the stop If certain information is unavailable, we ask for partial fulfillment of the data request. We also ask for the data to be provided in a machine readable format such as a csv file. An example for the type of data and format we are interested in is posted for New York City here:https://www1.nyc.gov/site/nypd/stats/reports-analysis/stopfrisk.page. Thank you for your consideration. If you have any questions or require further information, please contact Andrew Miller, 410-293-6844, millera@usna.edu

Janet Gagliano Dear Sir or Madam, Pursuant to the state open records law Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 4, sec. 7, cl. 26; ch. 66, secs. 10 to 18, on behalf of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP ("PwC"), I am writing to request copies of the Massachusetts - City of Boston - Treasury Department’s financial records concerning unclaimed, uncashed, undeliverable, and/or outstanding funds or obligations due back to non-individuals (businesses), including any and all: • Checks or warrants issued for payments on obligations incurred by any agency, department, office, or other authorized authority that have remained outstanding. • Amounts on deposit that are held in trust for recipients whose whereabouts are unknown, including instances in which payment was never attempted, payment was never requested, and/or instances when payments were returned as undeliverable. Such payments may relate to (but are not limited to) tax refunds/overages/refunds, overpayments, vendor payments, cash deposits, cash escrows, and unsuccessful electronic fund transfers. Criteria • Amount is greater than $999.99; • Payee retains the right to claim the funds (i.e. The payment has not been replaced, was not issued in error, and/or the obligation to the payee has not been voided by law.); • Is owed/payable to a business (corporations, partnerships, etc); • Has remained outstanding for a period of six months or longer; • Are not in the process of being reissued, to the best of your knowledge; and • Has not been turned over to a State Abandoned Property Office. Requested Data Columns: • Owner name (Required); • Amount (Required); • Original payment date (Required); • Check number; • Address; • Nature of the funds (i.e. vendor payment, property tax refund, etc.); and • If tax-related: o Name of the taxpayer and/or intended recipient; o Account number or property index number (PIN); and o Tax year; tax installment date; original tax payment date. Kindly email the records preferably in Excel or CSV format to us_aupdata@pwc.com. Records Schedule (if applicable): If the requested records are routinely prepared and released on a set schedule, please provide me with the frequency of the records (e.g. monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, annually) and when the records are records are typically available (e.g. 1st day of each month, annually on December 31st, etc.). Disclaimer: • PwC is NOT requesting records pertaining to the State’s Abandoned/Unclaimed Property Department. • PwC is only interested in receiving records pertaining to non-natural persons (businesses). PwC is not seeking any records which could invoke a personal privacy exemption. • None of the information requested by PwC will be used to solicit owners or third parties. If any of the requested information above is restricted by state statute, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. If your agency does not maintain these public records and/or you are not the custodian, please provide me with the proper custodian’s name and email address. Please notify me for approval if there are any costs associated with fulfilling this request. I will expect your response within the timeframe as specified by state statute pertaining to open records law. If you choose to deny this request, please provide me with a written explanation for the denial including a reference to the specific statutory exemption(s) upon which you rely. If you have any questions, please email us_aupdata@pwc.com. Thank you for your time and assistance. Sincerely,

Ballot Log – a per ballot report of every ballot in the sequence processed for the November 3, 2020 election: File format: any of CSV, delimited text or Microsoft .xlsx including column headers Columns: For each ballot, all available including, but not limited to: • Sequential ID • Timestamp • Ballot Type • Specific vote contained for all races • Batch ID • Tabulator ID Should any fields not be available, please include the fields which are. Voting Results Report Machine Tapes (tabulator tapes) from the Nov. 3, 2020 general election • Picture of the full tape in a PDF file and signed by clerk Any documentation that shows the machines were zeroed out prior to use on Nov. 3, 2020. (MA Gen L ch 54 § 35) Please respond within 10 business days. Please notify me if any of the requested items are not available. Peirce Peace My name is Peirce Peace. I am currently a Master's in Public Administration (MPA) student at the University of Massachusetts -Lowell. We as final semester students are asked to complete a capstone project in a desired area of study. Given that I am a student within the Justice Administration concentration, I thought my research topic should focus on the 2020 Massachusetts Police Reform Bill as it pertains to newly adopted use of force measures. Currently, I seek to examine the effectiveness of the freshly enacted 2020 Police Reform bill. Specifically, as a researcher I am trying to analyze use of force data across the state of Massachusetts. I am trying to determine and contribute to the conclusion of if this bill is working in the manner that in which it was intended to. To complete and come to a conclusive answer to this research question, I would need data to represent use of force incidences from the Boston Police Department. We have chosen Boston Police as one of our jurisdictions due to city population to officer ratio. If possible, is there a method to provide access to this information for the purposes of this project? The data would simply be a running total or count of use of force reports preadoption of the 2020 police reform and after enactment of the 2020 police reform, and type of force reported in these occurrences. Respectfully Submitted, Peirce A. Peace

William Gens Gens, Stanton, & Florek Request for Information Regarding the Implementation of City of Boston COVID-19 Vaccination mandate - Pursuant to M.G.L. Chapter 66 Section 10 Our office previously made a formal request to Dr. Ojkutu on February 4, 2022 through Certified First Class Returned Receipt Mail. We are now reaching out here, with our request. Please be advised that this office represents Boston First Responders United, a consolidated association consisting of hundreds of members of Boston Police, Firefighters, EMTs, and teachers including Sgt. Shana Cottone individually. Please take this letter as a formal request pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law (M.G.L. Chapter 66, Section 10) for the following information. With regard to your sworn affidavit in the matter of Boston Police Superior Officers Federation et al., v. Michelle Wu, Docket # 2284CV00001, Suffolk Superior Court, in which you state in paragraph 14 that your opinion “is informed by ... the best available medical and public health data” and further state in paragraph 15 that “individuals who are vaccinated are less likely to contract COVID-19 than those who are not.” Please provide all such data in your possession that you rely upon in forming your opinion that “individuals who are vaccinated are less likely to contract COVID-19 than those who are not.” Please be advised that this request interprets "data" as hard scientific evidence consisting of controlled trials, laboratory tests and studies, and peer-reviewed research papers. This request does NOT seek as scientific data: pronouncements, theories, or opinions of scientific authorities such as the Center for Disease Control, the World Health Organization, the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Anthony Fauci, and the like. This request is narrowly concerned with scientific data as defined above supporting the proposition that “individuals who are vaccinated are less likely to contract COVID-19 than those who are not.” I recognize that you may charge reasonable costs for copies of records, as well as for personnel time needed to comply with this request. The Public Records Law requires you to provide me with a written response within 10 business days. If you cannot comply with my request, you are statutorily required to provide an explanation in writing. Attached you will find our previous request to Dr. Ojikutu and the confirmation of mail service. Thank you for your assistance in this matter and please do not hesitate to contact me should you have any questions. Sincerely, William E. Gens, Esq. CiovO\

William Gens Gens, Stanton, & Florek Request for Information Regarding the Boston Public Health Commission's Claims of Vaccine Safety Our office previously made a formal request to the Boston Public Health Commission on February 4, 2022 through Certified First Class Returned Receipt Mail. We are now reaching out here, with our request. Please be advised that this office represents Boston First Responders United, a consolidated association consisting of hundreds of members of Boston Police, firefighters, EMTs, and teachers including Sgt. Shana Cottone individually. Please take this letter as a formal request pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law (M.G.L. Chapter 66, Section 10) for the following information. Request #1: With regard to the Boston Public Health Commission's publication entitled “Vaccine Myths and Facts” located at https://bphc.org/whatwedo/infectious diseases/Infectious-Diseases-A- to-Z/Pages/Vaccination-Myths-and-Facts.aspx, (a printed copy is attached for your reference),: stating in “Myth 2": “Vaccines are very safe. Before a vaccine is approved for public use it is tested thoroughly for many years." Please provide all documents in your possession constituting, summarizing, or analyzing long-term testing for many years” of the COVID vaccines that are mandated by the City of Boston. Request #2: With regard to the attached tweet of the Boston Public Health Commission dated May 13, 2021, (a copy of which is attached for your reference), stating that: “All 3 vaccines are safe and effective.” Please provide all scientific data you rely upon for the long-term safety of the vaccines in characterizing them as “safe.” Be advised that this request interprets "data” as hard scientific evidence consisting of controlled trials, laboratory tests and studies, and peer- reviewed research papers. This request does NOT seek as scientific data: pronouncements, theories, or opinions of scientific authorities such as the Center for Disease Control, the World Health Organization, the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Anthony Fauci, and the like. This request is narrowly concerned with scientific data as defined above supporting the proposition that “COVID vaccines are very safe” and have been "tested thoroughly for many years." I recognize that you may charge reasonable costs for copies of records, as well as for personnel time needed to comply with this request. The Public Records Law requires you to provide me with a written response within 10 business days. If you cannot comply with my request, you are statutorily required to provide an explanation in writing. Attached you will find our previous request to the Boston Public Health Commission and the confirmation of mail service.Thank you for your assistance in this matter and please do not hesitate to contact me should you have any questions. Sincerely, William E. Gens, Esq. ATTACHMENTS: 1. Boston Public Health Commission “Vaccination Myths and Facts," https://bphc.org/whatwedo/infectious-diseases/Infectious Diseases-A-to Z/Pages/Vaccination-Myths-and-Facts.aspx 2. Boston Public Health Commission twitter account “@HealthyBoston” tweet dated May 13, 2021. https://twitter.com/Healthy Boston/status/1392887482891571208

Alex Willenbring Utilimarc Hello, I am looking to make a public records request, if you are not the correct person to contact, it would be greatly appreciated if you could point me in the right direction of who to make the request to. I am requesting information on vehicles and off-road equipment maintained by the municipality's fleet department during the calendar year of 2021. “Vehicles” in this request would include police vehicles, ambulances, fire trucks, plows, refuse trucks, pickup trucks, service trucks, vans, sedans, motorcycles, etc. “Off-road equipment” in this request would include trailers, lawn mowers, generators, backhoes, trenchers, excavators, dozers, street sweepers, etc. The information requested for each vehicle or off-road equipment should include: ID Number, Status code, Class code, Unit Description, Make, Model, Model Year, VIN, In Service Date, Disposal Date (if applicable), Total Purchase Price, Annual Lease Cost, Annual Depreciation Cost, Annual Mechanic Labor Cost, Annual Vendor Cost, Annual Parts Cost, Annual Fuel Cost, Annual Labor Hours, Annual Miles Driven, Annual Fuel Gallons Consumed, Life-to-date Miles Driven I am also requesting information on employees who worked within the municipality's fleet department during the calendar year of 2021. An “employee” in this request could include a mechanic, serviceman, foreman, parts person, apprentice mechanic, analyst, clerk, fleet manager, or other administrative positions. The information requested for each employee should include: a unique identifier such as an employee name or id number, job title, hire date, leave date (if employee no longer works with municipality), base wage or salary, loaded wage or salary (including benefits). We understand that you may not want to provide specific employee information, thus feel free to replace an employee name or id with a random placeholder. Only an aggregate of this information will be utilized for our purpose. This data is typically stored in a Fleet Management Information System (FMIS). We are familiar with a variety of FMISs if help is needed in extracting information. We can also provide a secure FTP site to assist in the transfer of relevant txt, csv, or xlsx files. We are conducting a study to better understand the cost of vehicles and equipment operated by municipal organizations. Raw information collected will only be used internally, but aggregate information may be made available to our clients through an online benchmark or pdf report. Attached are templates to help identify the types of information we are looking for at a unit specific and employee level. If you have any questions, please reach out to my email, awillenbring@utilimarc.com , or at my phone number 651-202-0640. Thank you, Alex

Tonya Alanez The Boston Globe Dear Sergeant Detective Boyle: This is a request under the Massachusetts Public Records Law (M. G. L. Chapter 66, Section 10). I am requesting that I be provided with a copy of the following records, which I would ask be sent in electronic form (such as a PDF or Word or Excel file), if possible: • Officer Matthew Morrissey's personal file We recognize that you may charge reasonable costs for copies, as well as for personnel time needed to comply with this request. Please notify us of the estimated costs before you start compiling the requested records. The Public Records Law requires you to provide me with a written response within 10 business days. If you cannot comply with my request, you are statutorily required to provide an explanation in writing. We have been told that we cannot have access to the records we are seeking because of an “open and ongoing investigation” but I do not believe that the records I am seeking are exempt. Exemption (f) to the Public Records Law does not create a blanket exemption. Rather, the burden rests on the Department to show as to each requested record that (i) the information contained “would probably so prejudice the possibility of effective law enforcement that such disclosure would not be in the public interest,” G.L. c. 4, § 7(26)(f), and (ii) the entire record must be withheld, rather than redacting the information that poses a “grave risk” of disclosing information contrary to the public interest. See Globe Newspaper Co. v. Police Comm’r, 419 Mass. 853, 858 (1995) (“the existence of some exempt information in a document will not justify cloture as to all of it because the right to access extends to any nonexempt segregable portion of a public record”) (citations omitted).

Steven Rich The Washington Post This is a request under the Massachusetts Public Records Act § 66-10 et seq. I hereby request disclosure of all metadata produced by body-worn cameras for the entire department since January 1, 2015 (or whenever the program started if more recent). The request is for an electronic copy or extract of data in a standard, machine-readable data format and all files in files rather than printed out. The data should include all information considered public and maintained within the computer system. If possible, data should include, but not be limited to, the following: - Start time of recording - End time of recording - Duration of recording - Location - Latitude - Longitude - Police district - Police officer - Why recording started (manual vs automatic activation) - Why recording ended (manual vs automatic activation) - Deletion status - Deletion reason If you regard any of the requested records as subject to exemption from required disclosure under the law, I hereby request that you exercise your discretion and disclose them nonetheless. If you decide to withhold any requested records, please do not deny the entire request and release information available under the law. If you cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or certain portions must be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed. I make this request on behalf of The Washington Post, a newspaper of general circulation in the Washington D.C. metropolitan area. The records disclosed pursuant to this request will be used in the preparation of news articles for dissemination to the public. Accordingly, I request that you waive all fees in the public interest because the furnishing of the information sought by this request will primarily benefit the public and is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government. If, however, you decline to waive all fees, I am prepared to pay, but request that you notify me if you plan to charge. If you have any questions about this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at steven.rich@washpost.com or at (202) 334-4345. I look forward to your response.

Please waive any fees and copying costs, including pursuant to 950 C.M.R. § 32.07. BU Law is a not-for-profit, non-partisan organization dedicated to the principles of liberty and equality. As the Massachusetts affiliate of the national BU Law, a not-for-profit, non-partisan organization, BU Law distributes information both within and outside of Massachusetts. Samuele Petruccelli The Dorchester Reporter Hope this request finds you healthy and well. My name is Sam and I'm a reporter looking to obtain public records through a FOIL request. The Redevelopment Authority collected economic indicators from 2013 to 2015. This data is posted on the city's "Analyze Boston" website. I'm requesting the latest data on variables the redevelopment authority was already collecting and posting online. I've attached the city's partial data set to this request for reference. Below are some more details. Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, M.G.L. c.66, §10, I hereby request the following records broken down by year and month from January 2015 until the time this request is completed: The number of domestic and international passengers at Logan Airport. The number of international flights at Logan Airport. The hotel occupancy rate in Boston. The average daily rate for a hotel in Boston. Boston's unemployment rate and Boston's labor force participation rate. The number of board approved development project (pipeline) units approved. The total development cost of approved projects. The square footage of approved projects. The number of construction jobs. The number of housing foreclosure petitions in Boston. The number of housing foreclosure deeds in Boston. The median housing sale price in Boston. The number of houses sold in Boston. The number of new housing construction permits, and the number of new affordable housing construction permits in Boston. I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. In the event that fees cannot be waived, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filed electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.
